Plasma-treatment strategy has become an important technique to modify heterogenous catalyst. Here, the plasma-treated Ru/CeO2 catalysts were synthesized and applied to dichloroethane (DCE) oxidation. Compared with the untreated catalysts (CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T), the plasma-treated catalysts (CeO2-P, Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP) show higher catalytic activity. Amongst, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst shows the highest activity (T90 =243 °C, TOFSSA=6.98 μmol·m−2·h−1 and Ea=26 kJ·mol−1). Based on various characterizations, it reveals that the plasma-treatment can enrich the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, promote the formation of acid sites, and strengthen the interaction between Ru and CeO2 support. The interaction benefits the dispersion of Ru species, forming more active sites to enhance the DCE conversion. The more acid sites can improve the HCl selectivity. Moreover, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst exhibits excellent thermal stability and water-resistance performance. This signification result promotes the development of catalysts by plasma-treated strategy, and its wide application in heterogenous catalysis. Graphical Abstract The plasma-treated Ru/CeO2-P catalyst showed excellent performance for the catalytic oxidation of dichloroethane. It was revealed that the plasma-treatment promotes the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and Brønsted acid sites, improving the dispersion of Ru, enhancing the interaction between Ru species and CeO2, and improving the catalytic activity and thermal stability of DCE oxidation. ga1 Keywords Metal-support interaction Plasma treatment Ru/CeO2 catalyst Catalytic combustion Dichloroethane Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are recognized as one major air pollutants, that not only pollute the ecological environment, but also damage human health [1,2] As one typical VOCs, the chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) exhibit obvious bioaccumulation potential and intractability, even also participate into the formation of ozone [3]. Compared with the ab-/adsorption methods, catalytic oxidation is considered as one promising method for CVOCs removal because of the high purification efficiency and energy-saving [4–6]. During the catalytic oxidation process, the broken of C-Cl bond needs high energy, and the catalyst deactivation is also caused by the reaction between chloride ions and the active component [7,8]. Therefore, catalyst design development is very crucial to achieving high activity, selectivity and stability in catalytic oxidation of CVOCs. Ceria dioxide (CeO2) has a high oxygen storage capacity and facile Ce4+/ Ce3+ redox cycles, that endows its wide application in catalytic oxidation of CVOCs [9,10]. During the oxidation process of CVOCs, CeO2 could boost the rate of oxidation reaction or even change the redox step, but inevitable rapid deactivation appeared due to the strong adsorption of inorganic chlorine species on the active sites [3]. To solve this issue, one approach is to introduce the acid sites on the CeO2 surface. Because the Lewis acid sites are beneficial to cleaving the C-Cl bonds, they promote the formation of HCl product [11]. For example, Dai et al. [12] prepared phosphate-functionalized CeO2 nanosheets for catalytic oxidation of DCE by adjusting the nature and profile of surface acid-basic sites. It indicated that the Lewis acid sites could promote the dissociation of C-Cl bond, and the Brønsted acid sites could accelerate the removal of adsorbed chlorine species showing an enhanced catalyst stability. Our group [13] prepared the SiO2-coated CeO2 (CeO2 @ SiO2) catalyst for DCE oxidation. It found that the CeO2 @ SiO2 catalyst shows good activity due to the existence of acid sites on its surface, that facilitated the adsorption and activation of DCE, and the abundant adsorbed oxygen species and fast oxygen mobility also contributed to high performance. The other approach is to improve the concentrations of oxygen vacancies and redox properties by doping transition metal or noble metal Ru. It has been demonstrated that the introduction of Ru could rapidly remove the adsorbed inorganic chlorine species through Deacon reaction [14,15], and improve the ability of the poisoning resistance [16]. Gu et al. [17] prepared Ru/CexAly catalysts by impregnation method for DCE oxidation. The results showed that the presence of Ru could increase the reducibility of catalysts, which was beneficial to oxidation and removal of Cl species from the surface, whereas the strong acid probably promoted the breaking of C-Cl. In spite of the role of noble metal active site, the metal-support interaction was an indispensable factor for the enhancement of catalyst activity and durability [18,19]. Hu et al. [20] synthesized Ru/CeO2 catalyst for the catalytic combustion of propane, and thought that the superior catalytic performance was mainly ascribed to the abundant oxygen vacancies, that was originated from the strong interaction between Ru species and CeO2. The strong metal-support interaction was also revealed in Pt/3DOM CeO2-Al2O3 catalyst, that resulted in rich surface-active oxygen species and enhanced redox properties [21]. Thus, the catalyst design for DCE oxidation is involved in the enrichment of surface-active sites, acid sites, and the strong metal-support interaction. Recently, non-thermal plasma technology has been used for the preparation and modification of catalyst, which could change the morphology, dispersion and particle size of catalyst, or create more defects on the catalyst surface for enhanced catalytic activity [22–25]. Yuan et al. [26] used plasma-engraved technique to modify the surface of Co3O4 nanostructures for formaldehyde oxidation. It showed that plasma-treatment could improve surface area and surface defects to boost the formaldehyde oxidation. The large surface area could provide more accessible active sites, and the abundant defects could boost the activation and transfer of oxygen. Wang et al. [27] synthesized the contrast CeO2 nanorods and Pt/CeO2 catalyst by the thermal calcination and/or plasma technique. It revealed that the plasma-treatment not only brought the signification variation of the surface morphologies and surface oxygen defects, but also promoted the surface interaction between Pt and CeO2 achieving a high thermal stability. On the one hand, plasma-treatment could improve the dispersion of Pt, and more Pt atoms are exposed on the surface to adsorb toluene molecules. Moreover, the interaction between Pt and CeO2 was obviously strengthened, leading to the improved redox capability after plasma-treatment. In short, plasma-treatment could improve the dispersion of noble metal, increase the surface area and surface defects, and metal-support interaction. Herein, the different Ru/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and subsequent thermal (Ru/CeO2-T), plasma (Ru/CeO2-P), and the combined (Ru/CeO2-TP) treatments ( Scheme 1). The prepared CeO2 nanorods and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were applied for the catalytic oxidation of DCE. On the basis of various characterizations, the structure-activity relationship was established. We found that the plasma-treatment strategy promotes the formation of surface defects and strengthens the interaction between Ru species and CeO2 support, which mainly contributes to superior performance. Finally, the stability and water resistance of Ru/CeO2 catalysts under conditions of DCE oxidation were also evaluated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of CeO2 nanorods The CeO2 nanorods were prepared by a hydrothermal method. Typically, 3.47 g Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O was dissolved in 20 mL deionized water to form a clear solution. Then, 140 mL NaOH (9 M) was added into the prepared solution with continuously stirring for 0.5 h. Then, the solution was transferred into a 200 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and hydrothermally treated at 100 °C for 24 h. After cooling, the solid products were centrifugated, washed, and dried at 80 °C. Finally, the obtained CeO2 nanorods were further calcined at 500 °C for 3 h and labeled as CeO2-T (where T represents thermal method). A part of CeO2-T was treated with dielectric barrier discharge plasma (the power was 40 W, and the time was 10 min) to obtain new CeO2 nanorods, and named as CeO2-P (where P means plasma treatment). 2.2 Preparation of Ru/CeO2 catalysts CeO2 supported Ru catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. 0.06 g RuCl3·3 H2O was dissolved in 30 mL deionized water and then added into 2.97 g CeO2 nanorods. After stirring for 30 min, the mixed solution was placed for 12 h, following by drying at 60 °C overnight. The dried precursors were calcined at 500 °C for 2 h and the catalysts were denoted as Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-P, respectively. As a contrast, a portion of Ru/CeO2-T catalyst was treated through dielectric barrier discharge plasma, in which the plasma treatment power was 40 W and the treatment time was 10 min. The obtained catalyst was named as Ru/CeO2-TP. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD, UV–visible diffuse reflectance, TEM, BET, H2-TPR, Raman, XPS and Py-IR experiments were employed to analyze the different catalysts. The detailed methods are described in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic combustion of DCE over all catalysts was tested in a continuous fixed-bed quartz reactor. The detailed reaction conditions are shown in the Supporting Information (SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of CeO2 nanorods and different Ru/CeO2 samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. All samples exhibit the characteristic peaks of CeO2 with cubic fluorite structure (JCPDS PDF#34–0394) [28]. However, no diffraction peaks of RuO2 or Ru could be observed in Ru/CeO2 samples, which might be attributed to the low loading content (ca. 1.0 wt%) along with high dispersion of Ru species, or the formation of the Ru-O-Ce solid solution [29]. Noticeably, a slight shift in the diffraction angles was observed for CeO2 nanorods after plasma-treatment (Fig. 1 b). It indicates that the plasma treatment could cause the lattice changes of CeO2 and induce the lattice distortion. After deposition of Ru in CeO2, the diffraction peaks shift to lower angles relative to the peaks of the CeO2 nanorods, which is attributed to the incorporation of Ru causing an expansion of the framework [30,31]. In addition, the crystalline sizes of all samples were also calculated by Scherrer formula, and the results are placed in Table 1. Through the comparison, it can be found that the CeO2 nanorods exhibit a slight shrinkage phenomenon after plasma-treatment, and the mean crystal sizes of CeO2 was reduced from 11.9 nm to 11.4 nm. Meanwhile, the similar result is also observed in supported Ru/CeO2 catalysts, such as Ru/CeO2-TP (11.6 nm) and Ru/CeO2-P (11.5 nm). It was reported that when the crystal size decreased with a lower Ce-O symmetry, the number of surface oxygen sites or oxygen vacancies increased for CeO2 sample [32]. Thus, it is reasonable to assume that the plasma-treatment can effectively boost the increase of surface oxygen vacancies. The N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the CeO2 nanorods and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were displayed in Fig. S1, and the physical parameters were also summarized in Table 1. All samples exhibit the characteristics of type Ⅳ isotherm with a hysteresis loop of H3 type in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.4–0.9 (Fig. S1a), indicated that the order mesoporous structure exist in all catalysts. According to the similar hysteresis loops, the deposition of Ru species and the plasma-treatment cannot change the microstructure of CeO2 matrix. The pore size distributions of all the samples were displayed in Fig. S1b, which were calculated from the BJH adsorption branch. The average pore sizes of different samples range from 6.4 to 7.4 nm. The pore size of plasma-treated CeO2-P is slightly larger than that of the untreated CeO2-T. Seen from Table 1, the surface areas of different samples are in the range of 86–104 m2/g, and the corresponding pore sizes change from 6.4 to 7.4 nm. Through the comparison, we found that the surface area and pore size show a slight increase after plasma-treatment. This phenomenon should be ascribed to the role of plasma-treatment, and the CeO2 nanorods were cracked and become shorter, exposing more surface area and pore structure [22]. The morphology of different samples was characterized by (HR)TEM. In Fig. S2, the CeO2 nanorods and their obvious lattice fringes are confirmed. Meanwhile, partial cracking occurs on the CeO2 nanorods after plasma-treatment. The TEM, SAED pattern (inset) and elemental mapping images of different Ru/CeO2 samples are shown in Fig. 2, no distinguishable Ru particles are observed except the CeO2 nanorods matrix, indicating the high dispersion or the formation of Ru-O-Ce solid solution. The pore structure is mostly stacked pore of nanorods, due to the shelter of smaller particles by larger ones (Fig S2(e-f)). All samples display clear (111), (200) and (220) lattices fringes of CeO2 with a respective interplanar spacing of 0.31 nm, 0.27 nm and 0.19 nm [27], respectively. Notably, the Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP samples show (002) lattice fringes with an interplanar spacing of 0.28 nm, which might be ascribed to the role of plasma-treatment. Furthermore, several distinct rings were observed through the SAED pattern (Fig. 2b, e and h), which was a powerful evidence of crystal phase structure of Ru/CeO2 catalysts. Seen from the elemental mappings (Fig. 2c, f and i), highly dispersed Ru species are observed in plasma-treated samples (Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP). It indicates that plasma-treatment is favorable to improve the dispersion of Ru species on the surface of CeO2, and this should be attributed to the abundant defect sites made by plasma-treatment [33], forming the ionic bonds with Ru. The Ru ionic entered oxygen vacancy of the crystal planes of CeO2 can improve the interaction between Ru species and CeO2 supports. The surface electronic states were obtained from UV-Vis diffuse reflectance measurement. The CeO2 nanorods and three Ru/CeO2 catalysts exhibit two absorption peaks at 267 nm and 218 nm ( Fig. 3a), which are assigned to the O2-→Ce4+ charge transfer and the O2-→Ce3+ charge transfer, respectively [34], the band at 374 nm can be attributed to inter-band transition. Compared with CeO2-T, the surface electronic states of plasma-treated CeO2 nanorods had no obvious change, but the position of adsorption edge was shifted to a smaller wavelength by plasma treatment, this blue shift may be the result of a decrease in particle size of ceria, or may be attributed to an increasing contribution of O2-→Ce4+ charge transfer. In addition, the introduction of Ru species greatly enhances the absorbance of CeO2 in the visible light region [28], and a clearly visible peak (400–500 nm) can be observed for Ru/CeO2-T, Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP. This feature can be assigned to the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) peak of Ru species supported on CeO2 nanorods [35]. The results revealed that there was a stronger interaction between Ru species and CeO2 nanorods. To study the role of oxygen vacancies, the UV-Raman spectra were employed to characterize the CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalysts. In Fig. 3 b, four typical peaks appear at 258, 460, 590 and 1172 cm−1. According to previous studies [36], the main peaks at 460 cm−1 could be attributed to the F2 g mode corresponding to the symmetrical stretching vibrations of Ce-O in the fluorite CeO2, while the peaks at 590 cm−1 could be assigned to the defect induced (D) mode that is related to the oxygen vacancies induced by the existence of Ce3+ ions of CeO2. The weak peaks at 260 cm−1 were attributed to second-order transverse acoustic (2TA) model, and the peaks at 1172 cm−1 were distinguished as a second-order longitudinal optical (2LO) model. The characteristic peaks of RuO2 were not detectable due to the low content of RuO2 or the interaction between Ru species and ceria in Ru/CeO2 samples. In addition, two new peaks at 694 and 968 cm−1 were observed after loading of Ru, which are indexed to the formation of the Ru-O-Ce bond between Ru and CeO2 nanorods supports, confirming the existence of strong interaction between Ru and CeO2 supports. Besides, no obvious shifts of UV-Raman peaks are observed. As it was reported that the relative ratio of ID/IF2g represents the relative concentration of oxygen vacancies [37]. The serial of ID/IF2g ratios were calculated in the following order, CeO2-T (ID/IF2g=0.088) < CeO2-P (ID/IF2g=0.109) < Ru/CeO2-T (ID/IF2g=0.211) < Ru/CeO2-TP (ID/IF2g=0.234) < Ru/CeO2-P (ID/IF2g=0.275). Apparently, the plasma-treated sample exhibits higher ID/IF2g ratio, indicative of more oxygen vacancies. And the oxygen vacancies are also correlated with the Ru-Ce interaction, resulting in electronic enrichment of the catalyst surface. H2-TPR was employed to investigate the redox properties of different CeO2 nanorods and Ru/CeO2 catalysts. The peaks in the high temperature region (> 600 ℃) can be attributed to reduction of lattice oxygen for CeO2 nanorods and Ru/CeO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the peaks in the low temperature region (400–500 ℃) are attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen of CeO2. After loading of Ru species on the nanorods supports, the reduction peaks of low temperature changed significantly. As for Ru/CeO2 catalysts, two obvious reduction peaks can be observed at 80–100 ℃ and 100–120 ℃ (Fig. 4 b). It means that the Ru species exist in two different states [38], and the Ru species strongly interacted with ceria surface could be reduced at a lower temperature, whereas the one that weakly interacted with the CeO2 supports was reduced at a relatively higher temperature. The reduction peaks centered at 90 ℃ could be assigned to the adsorbed oxygen or well dispersed Ru species interacting strongly with CeO2 surface [34]. The reduction peaks in the range of 100–120 °C could be attributed to the reduction of weakly interacted with CeO2 surface [18]. Compared to Ru/CeO2-T, the reduction peak of plasma-treated samples (Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP) shifts to lower reduction temperature, which is attributed to the Ce-O bond weakened by the strongly bound Ru species [39]. Additionally, the amount of H2 consumptions of CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 with different temperature ranges are shown in Table 1. We found that the H2 consumption of CeO2-P is higher than that of CeO2-T in low temperature region, implying that plasma-treatment could increase more reductive species on CeO2 surface to speed up reduction. The high H2 consumption should be ascribed to the existence of Ru-O-Ce, which promotes the reduction of surface oxygen. The amounts of H2 consumption of Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP are still higher than that of Ru/CeO2-T, suggesting that the interaction between Ru species and CeO2 supports is improved by plasma-treatment. To further reveal the distribution of surface acidity, the catalysts were characterized by Py-IR [40,41], and the results are shown in Fig. 5 a. The adsorption peaks centered at 1440 and 1587 cm−1 in all samples correspond to the characteristic vibration peaks of pyridine molecule adsorbed at Lewis acid sites [42]. As for CeO2 nanorods, the adsorption peaks centered at 1545 and 1484 cm−1 in CeO2-P are attributed to the characteristic vibration peaks of pyridine molecule adsorbed at Brønsted acid sites and the synergistic effect between Lewis acid and Brønsted acid, respectively. It indicates that plasma-treatment is favorable to the formation of Brønsted acid sites. Compared to Ru/CeO2-T catalyst, the peaks at 1635 and 1538 cm−1 could be observed in Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP catalysts, which is attributed to the characteristic vibration peaks of pyridine molecule adsorbed at Brønsted acid sites [43], indicating that plasma-treatment is favorable to the formation of Brønsted acid sites. In order to investigate the thermal stability of acid sites, the CeO2-T and CeO2-P catalysts were also characterized by In-situ Py-IR. In Fig. 5 b, the plasma-treated CeO2 nanorods have stronger Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites compared to the untreated CeO2 nanorods. It suggests that plasma-treatment facilitates the adsorption and activation of DCE on the CeO2 catalysts and the removal of Cl species. As it was reported that the adsorbed Cl- species could be removed in the form of HCl with the aid of Brønsted acid sites. Meanwhile, the dissociation of HCl to Cl- form could be inhibited through Brønsted acid sites, which could improve the anti-poisoning property of catalyst [44]. XPS measurement was performed to investigate the surface composition and chemical state of CeO2 nanorods and Ru/CeO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. (6a and S3a), the Ce 3d XPS spectra are fitted into two components peaks of Ce3+ and Ce4+. The characteristic peaks (u, u″, u‴, v, v″ and v‴) are assigned to the Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 of Ce4+. The other two characteristic peaks u′ and v′ are ascribed to Ce3+ 3d3/2 and Ce3+ 3d5/2 [45,46], which would generally serve as an indicator of the oxygen vacancies on the ceria surface. In addition, the plasma treated catalysts have a higher Ce3+ proportion (CeO2-P, 18.8%; Ru/CeO2-P, 25.1%; Ru/CeO2-TP, 22.4%) than the untreated catalysts (CeO2-T, 15.6%; Ru/CeO2-T, 19.8%), indicating that a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies form via plasma-treatment (Fig. 6d and Table 2). The O 1 s XPS spectra are fitted to three kinds of oxygen species, and displayed in Fig. (6b and S3b). The binding energy at 529.8 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (O2-), and the peak at 531.9 eV is assigned to surface oxygen species (O2 2- or O-), and the form of hydroxyl OH- carbonate CO3 2- species and adsorbed molecular water is regarded as adsorption oxygen (the binding energy at 532.9 eV) [47,48]. Clearly, the plasma-treated samples (CeO2-P, Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP) had more surface oxygen species (O2 2- or O-) compared to CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T (Fig. 6d and Table 2). The increased amounts of surface oxygen are 4.6%, 18.1% and 10.2%, respectively. As well-known, more surface oxygen species in the catalyst would make it easier to oxidize DCE. The XPS spectra of Ru 3p are placed in Fig. 6 c and corresponding parameters are listed in Table 2. All catalysts displayed two Ru 3p3/2 peaks at 463.5 and 464.5 eV, corresponding to the Ru4+ and Ru6+ species, respectively. No characteristic peak of Ru0 is detected at 461.0 eV [49]. As well-known, the presence of Run+ is due to the interaction between Ru and CeO2 support, in which the electron transfer from Ru to CeO2 [50,51]. The interaction between metal with support could significantly affect the concentration of oxygen vacancies and the catalytic performances. Moreover, compared with Ru/CeO2-T, the relative content of Ru4+ (Ru4+/(Ru4++Ru6+)) shows an increase of 9.4% and 5.7% for Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP, respectively (Table 2). It is noticeable that plasma-treated catalysts have a greater amount of Ru4+ species. Compared to Ru6+ species, the Ru4+ species could insert into the surface lattice of CeO2 to increase the concentration of oxygen vacancies. The results indicate that the introduction of Ru leads to the following reaction: 2Ce4++Ru4+→2Ce3++Ru6+. From Fig. 6d, the relative content of Ce3+ and Ru4+ is the highest in Ru/CeO2-P, indicating that the interaction between metal Ru and CeO2 nanorods is strongest, and plasma treatment could enhance the interaction between Ru and CeO2 supports. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability The activities of various CeO2 and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were evaluated in catalytic oxidation DCE. Seen from Fig. 7a, the DCE conversions of all catalysts increase with an increase of reaction temperature, and the catalytic activities follow the order: Ru/CeO2-P > Ru/CeO2-TP > Ru/CeO2-T > CeO2-P > CeO2-T. The DCE conversion of CeO2-P is obviously higher than that of CeO2-T at the same temperature. And the plasma-treated catalysts (Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP) also show superior performance compared with the Ru/CeO2-T catalyst. Amongst these catalysts, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst exhibits the highest activity, with a T90 (the temperature corresponding to the 90% DCE conversion) of 243 °C. Clearly, the activities of catalysts are boosted by plasma-treatment. Generally, the exposed Ru atoms are regarded as active sites that could strongly adsorb DCE molecules and activate them into dehydrogenated intermediates [52]. Through the plasma-treatment, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst processes higher dispersion and more exposed Ru atoms on the surface, that contributes to its high catalytic performance. Another important reason might be ascribed to the increase of oxygen vacancies concentration and the acid sites, which were also regarded as reactive sites strongly affecting the catalytic activity [53,54]. Moreover, the selectivities of HCl and Cl2 in DCE oxidation were also presented in Fig. 7b-c. During catalytic oxidation of DCE, chorine-related products were mainly in the form of HCl and Cl2, and no chlorinated organic byproducts over Ru/CeO2 catalysts. However, except for the HCl and Cl2, several chlorinated byproducts were also detected in the process of DCE oxidation by CeO2 catalysts, such as vinyl chloride (VC) and dichloroethylene (Fig. S4). Obviously, the VC was the main byproduct in the oxidation of DCE over CeO2 catalysts, which was the intermediate formed by dehydrochlorination of DCE at the acid sites. It can be seen that the HCl selectivities of all catalysts decrease obviously with a rise of reaction temperature. Because the HCl product is easily converted into Cl2 under Ru-based catalysts through Deacon reaction especially at high temperature [55], leading to the decrease of HCl selectivity. As for the Ru/CeO2 catalysts, the selectivities of Cl2 showed an increasing trend with the increase of temperature (Fig. 7c), which was because the introduction of Ru species can enhance the redox ability, leading to the formation of Cl2. Except the CeO2-T catalyst, the HCl selectivities of other catalysts are still kept at ca. 85% at 250 °C. The lower HCl selectivity should be attributed to the strong redox properties, and the plasma-treatment indeed promotes the redox capabilities of catalysts according to the H2-TPR results. In order to eliminate the role of surface area, the TOFSSA values based on surface area were calculated ( Table 3 and Fig. 7d). The TOFSSA values are 1.22 μmol·m−2·h−1 (CeO2-T), 3.45 μmol·m−2·h−1(CeO2-P), 3.82 μmol·m−2·h−1 (Ru/CeO2-T), 6.98 μmol·m−2·h−1 (Ru/CeO2-P) and 5.74 μmol·m−2·h−1 (Ru/CeO2-TP). Apparently, the plasma-treated catalysts have higher specific reaction rates, implying that the surface area is not the sole factor determining the superior performance. On the basis of above characterizations, the plasma-treated catalyst has more surface oxygen vacancies and strong metal-support interaction, which also contributes to the high activity. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for DCE oxidation over different catalysts were also shown in Fig. 7e. From the Arrhenius plots of the rate constant k over CeO2-based catalysts obtained with low conversion (< 20%), the Ea values for oxidation of DCE were calculated to be in the following order: CeO2-T (67 kJ·mol−1) > CeO2-P (46 kJ·mol−1) > Ru/CeO2-T (37 kJ·mol−1) > Ru/CeO2-TP (27 kJ·mol−1) ≈ Ru/CeO2-P (26 kJ·mol−1). Compared to single CeO2 supports, the Ru/CeO2 catalysts show lower Ea values. Meanwhile, the plasma-treated catalysts also have lower Ea values. It indicates that the plasma-treatment strategy can effectively reduce the activation energy of catalyst, boosting the activation and oxidation of DCE. The stability of the catalysts is an important factor in the industrial application. Hence, the stability of three Ru/CeO2 catalysts was examined with consecutive catalytic runs and evaluation of long-term catalytic performance of DCE oxidation. Durability test of CeO2-T, CeO2-P, Ru/CeO2-T, Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP catalysts were carried out at 250 °C within 12 h (Fig. 7f). As for CeO2 supports, the DCE conversion of CeO2-P shows no obvious decrease, while the DCE conversion of CeO2-T decreases from 68% to 51% (Fig. S5). The DCE conversions of Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP catalysts present no obvious decrease during 12 h test, whereas the DCE conversion of Ru/CeO2-T catalyst decreases from 80% to 65%. These results indicate that the Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP catalysts have good stability, which might be attributed to the high dispersion of Ru atoms and the strong interaction between Ru species and CeO2 support [56,57]. In order to understand the effect of humidity on DCE oxidation over the Ru/CeO2 catalysts, and the stability of the catalysts under the simulated real exhaust conditions with water was performed. Fig. 7g shows the conversion of DCE with 5 vol% water vapors over the range 3–6 h. When the 5 vol% water vapor was introduced into the system at 250 °C, the catalytic activity decreases from 93% to 89%. The cause of decreased activity should be attributed to the competitive attachment of H2O to the active sites. The DCE conversion was restored to its initial value when the water vapor was cut off, indicating that the deactivation is reversible. The DCE conversion rate remains nearly unchanged in thermal-resistance cycling test between 250 °C and 300 °C (Fig. 7h). This means that the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst displays superior water-resistance and heat-resistance performance. To deeply understand the possible change of crystal phase structures of the catalysts after DCE catalytic combustion, the XRD and XPS techniques were used to characterize the used Ru/CeO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8a, only the characteristic peaks of CeO2 can be clearly observed for all Ru/CeO2 samples, and no obvious characteristic peaks of chlorate are detected, implying that the crystal phase structure remains unbroken. Fig. 8(b-d) displays the XPS spectra of Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-P samples, the relative content of Ce3+ species and surface oxygen species concentration were also listed in Table 2 . The concentrations of Ce3+ species in Ru/CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-P catalysts show a slight change. The concentrations of surface oxygen species in Ru/CeO2-T catalyst decrease from 32.9% to 26.0%, whereas the ones decrease slightly from 51.0% to 50.6% for Ru/CeO2-P catalyst. These results mean that the decline in surface oxygen species is closely related to the adsorption of inorganic species on the oxygen vacancies, resulting poor performance in stability test. 4 Conclusion In summary, the CeO2 nanorods was synthesized by a hydrothermal method, and the Ru/CeO2 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and subsequent thermal (Ru/CeO2-T), plasma (Ru/CeO2-P), and the combined (Ru/CeO2-TP) treatments. In catalytic oxidation of DCE, the plasma-treated catalysts show the superior performance compared with the untreated catalysts. Among these catalysts, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst shows the highest catalytic activity with a T90 of 243 °C, and the TOFSSA value of 6.98 μmol·m−2·h−1, and the lowest activation energy of 26 kJ·mol−1. Based on various characterizations, the superior performance should be attributed to the role of plasma-treatment, which enriches the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies and strengthen the interaction between Ru and CeO2 support, benefiting to the dispersion of Ru species. Moreover, plasma-treated Ru/CeO2-P catalyst still possesses excellent thermal stability and water-resistance performance in catalytic oxidation of DCE. This significant result promotes the development of catalytic materials by plasma-treated strategy, and their wide application in heterogenous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Plasma-treatment strategy has become an important technique to modify heterogenous catalyst. Here, the plasma-treated Ru/CeO2 catalysts were synthesized and applied to dichloroethane (DCE) oxidation. Compared with the untreated catalysts (CeO2-T and Ru/CeO2-T), the plasma-treated catalysts (CeO2-P, Ru/CeO2-P and Ru/CeO2-TP) show higher catalytic activity. Amongst, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst shows the highest activity (T90 =243 °C, TOFSSA=6.98 μmol·m−2·h−1 and Ea=26 kJ·mol−1). Based on various characterizations, it reveals that the plasma-treatment can enrich the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, promote the formation of acid sites, and strengthen the interaction between Ru and CeO2 support. The interaction benefits the dispersion of Ru species, forming more active sites to enhance the DCE conversion. The more acid sites can improve the HCl selectivity. Moreover, the Ru/CeO2-P catalyst exhibits excellent thermal stability and water-resistance performance. This signification result promotes the development of catalysts by plasma-treated strategy, and its wide application in heterogenous catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Improved metal-support interaction in Ru/CeO2 catalyst via plasma-treated strategy for dichloroethane oxidation
